docs.title: Format
docs.text: ST_DistanceSphere (A: Geometry, B: Geometry)

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text:
• geomA: Input geometry or geography.
  • geomB: Input geometry or geography.

docs.title: SQL Example
docs.text: SELECT ST_DistanceSphere(ST_GeomFromText('POLYGON ((10 10, 11 10, 10 11, 10 10))'), ST_GeomFromText('POLYGON ((0 0, 1 0, 0 1, 0 0))')) AS val

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Calculates the spheroidal (ellipsoidal) distance between geomA and geomB.

docs.title: Format
docs.text: ST_DistanceSpheroid (A: Geometry, B: Geometry)

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text:
• geomA: Input geometry or geography.
  • geomB: Input geometry or geography.

docs.title: SQL Example
docs.text: SELECT ST_DistanceSpheroid(ST_GeomFromText('POLYGON ((10 10, 11 10, 10 11, 10 10))'), ST_GeomFromText('POLYGON ((0 0, 1 0, 0 1, 0 0))')) AS val

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Returns true if two geometries are within a specified distance of each other.

docs.title: Format
docs.text: ST_DWithin (A: Geometry, B: Geometry, distance: Double)

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text:
• geomA: Input geometry or geography.
  • geomB: Input geometry or geography.
  • distance: Distance in units of the geometry's coordinate system.

docs.title: SQL Example
docs.text: SELECT ST_DWithin(ST_Point(0.25, 0.25), ST_GeomFromText('POLYGON ((0 0, 1 0, 0 1, 0 0))'), 0.5);

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Returns the bounding box (envelope) of a geometry as a new geometry. The resulting geometry represents the minimum bounding rectangle that encloses the input geometry. Depending on the input, the output can be a Point, LineString, or Polygon.

docs.title: Format
docs.text: ST_Envelope (A: Geometry)

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: • geom: The input geometry.

docs.title: SQL Example
docs.text: SELECT ST_Envelope(ST_Point(1.0, 2.0))

docs.title: Description
docs.text: An aggregate function that returns the collective bounding box (envelope) of a set of geometries.

docs.title: Format
docs.text: ST_Envelope_Aggr (geom: Geometry)

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: • geom: A column of geometries to be aggregated.

docs.title: SQL Example
docs.text:
-- Create a table with geometries and calculate the aggregate envelope
WITH shapes(geom) AS (
    VALUES (ST_GeomFromWKT('POINT (0 1)')),
           (ST_GeomFromWKT('POINT (10 11)'))
)
SELECT ST_AsText(ST_Envelope_Aggr(geom)) FROM shapes;
-- Returns: POLYGON ((0 1, 0 11, 10 11, 10 1, 0 1))

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Return true if geomA equals geomB.

docs.title: Format
docs.text: ST_Equals (A: Geometry, B: Geometry)

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text:
• geomA: Input geometry or geography.
  • geomB: Input geometry or geography.

docs.title: SQL Example
docs.text: SELECT ST_Equals(ST_Point(0.25 0.25), ST_GeomFromText('POLYGON ((0 0, 1 0, 0 1, 0 0))')) AS val

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Returns a new geometry with the X and Y coordinates of each vertex swapped. This is useful for correcting geometries that have been created with longitude and latitude in the wrong order.

docs.title: Format
docs.text: ST_FlipCoordinates (A: geometry)

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: • geom: The input geometry whose coordinates will be flipped.

docs.title: SQL Example
docs.text: SELECT ST_FlipCoordinates(df.geometry)

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Calculates the Frechet distance between geomA and geomB.

docs.title: Format
docs.text: ST_FrechetDistance (A: Geometry, B: Geometry)

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text:
• geomA: Input geometry or geography.
  • geomB: Input geometry or geography.

docs.title: SQL Example
docs.text: SELECT ST_FrechetDistance(ST_GeomFromText('POLYGON ((10 10, 11 10, 10 11, 10 10))'), ST_GeomFromText('POLYGON ((0 0, 1 0, 0 1, 0 0))')) AS val

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Construct a Geometry from WKB.

docs.title: Format
docs.text: ST_GeomFromWKB (Wkb: Binary)

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: • WKB: binary: Well-known binary representation of the geometry.

docs.title: SQL Example
docs.text:
-- Creates a POINT(1 2) geometry from its WKB representation
SELECT ST_AsText(ST_GeomFromWKB(FROM_HEX('0101000000000000000000F03F0000000000000040')));

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Construct a Geometry from WKT. This function also has the alias ST_GeomFromText.

docs.title: Format
docs.text: ST_GeomFromWKT (Wkt: String)

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: • WKT: string: Well-known text representation of the geometry.

docs.title: SQL Example
docs.text: SELECT ST_AsText(ST_GeomFromWKT('POINT (30 10)'));

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Return the type of a geometry.

docs.title: Format
docs.text: ST_GeometryType (A: Geometry)

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: • geom: Input geometry.

docs.title: SQL Example
docs.text: SELECT ST_GeometryType(ST_GeomFromWKT('POLYGON ((0 0, 1 0, 0 1, 0 0))'))

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Return true if the geometry has a M dimension.

docs.title: Format
docs.text: ST_HasM (A: Geometry)

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: • geom: Input geometry.

docs.title: SQL Example
docs.text: SELECT ST_HasM(ST_GeomFromWKT('POLYGON ((0 0, 1 0, 0 1, 0 0))'))

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Return true if the geometry has a Z dimension.

docs.title: Format
docs.text: ST_HasZ (A: Geometry)

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: • geom: Input geometry.

docs.title: SQL Example
docs.text: SELECT ST_HasZ(ST_GeomFromWKT('POLYGON ((0 0, 1 0, 0 1, 0 0))'))

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Calculates the Hausdorff distance between geomA and geomB.

docs.title: Format
docs.text: ST_HausdorffDistance (A: Geometry, B: Geometry)

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text:
• geomA: Input geometry or geography.
  • geomB: Input geometry or geography.

docs.title: SQL Example
docs.text: SELECT ST_HausdorffDistance(ST_GeomFromText('POLYGON ((10 10, 11 10, 10 11, 10 10))'), ST_GeomFromText('POLYGON ((0 0, 1 0, 0 1, 0 0))')) AS val

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Computes the intersection between geomA and geomB.

docs.title: Format
docs.text: ST_Intersection (A: Geometry, B: Geometry)

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text:
• geomA: Input geometry or geography.
  • geomB: Input geometry or geography.

docs.title: SQL Example
docs.text: SELECT ST_Intersection(ST_GeomFromText('POLYGON ((1 1, 11 1, 1 11, 0 0))'), ST_GeomFromText('POLYGON ((0 0, 10 0, 0 10, 0 0))')) AS val

docs.title: Description
docs.text: An aggregate function that returns the geometric intersection of all geometries in a set.

docs.title: Format
docs.text: ST_Intersection_Aggr (geom: Geometry)

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: • geom: A column of geometries to be aggregated.

docs.title: SQL Example
docs.text:
-- Create a table with overlapping polygons and find their common intersection
WITH shapes(geom) AS (
    VALUES (ST_GeomFromWKT('POLYGON((0 0, 2 0, 2 2, 0 2, 0 0))')),
           (ST_GeomFromWKT('POLYGON((1 1, 3 1, 3 3, 1 3, 1 1))'))
)
SELECT ST_AsText(ST_Intersection_Aggr(geom)) FROM shapes;
-- Returns: POLYGON ((1 1, 1 2, 2 2, 2 1, 1 1))

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Return true if geomA intersects geomB.

docs.title: Format
docs.text: ST_Intersects (A: Geometry, B: Geometry)

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text:
• geomA: Input geometry or geography.
  • geomB: Input geometry or geography.

docs.title: SQL Example
docs.text: SELECT ST_Intersects(ST_Point(0.25 0.25), ST_GeomFromText('POLYGON ((0 0, 1 0, 0 1, 0 0))')) AS val

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Return true if the geometry is empty.

docs.title: Format
docs.text: ST_IsEmpty (A: Geometry)

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: • geom: Input geometry.

docs.title: SQL Example
docs.text: SELECT ST_IsEmpty(ST_GeomFromWKT('POLYGON EMPTY'));

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Return true if geomA finds k nearest neighbors from geomB.

docs.title: Format
docs.text: ST_KNN (A: Geometry, B: Geometry, k: Integer, use_spheroid: Boolean)

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text:
• geomA: Query geometry or geography.
  • geomB: Object geometry or geography.
  • k: Number of nearest neighbors to find.
  • use_spheroid: Use spheroid distance calculation.

docs.title: SQL Example
docs.text: SELECT * FROM table1 a JOIN table2 b ON ST_KNN(a.geom, b.geom, 5, false)

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Returns the length of geom. This function only supports LineString, MultiLineString, and GeometryCollections containing linear geometries. Use ST_Perimeter for polygons.

docs.title: Format
docs.text: ST_Length (A: Geometry)

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: • geom: geometry: Input geometry.

docs.title: SQL Example
docs.text: SELECT ST_Length(ST_GeomFromWKT('LINESTRING(0 0, 10 0)'));

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Returns the M (measure) coordinate of a Point geometry. If the geometry does not have an M value, it returns NULL.

docs.title: Format
docs.text: ST_M (A: Point)

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: • geom: The input point geometry or geography.

docs.title: SQL Example
docs.text: SELECT ST_M(ST_Point(1.0, 2.0))

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Creates a LineString from two or more input Point, MultiPoint, or LineString geometries. The function connects the input geometries in the order they are provided to form a single continuous line.

docs.title: Format
docs.text: ST_MakeLine (g1: Geometry or Geography, g2: Geometry or Geography)

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text:
• g1: The first Point, MultiPoint, or LineString geometry or geography.
  • g2: The second Point, MultiPoint, or LineString geometry or geography.

docs.title: SQL Example
docs.text: SELECT ST_MakeLine(ST_Point(0, 1), ST_Point(2, 3)) as geom

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Calculates the maximum distance between geomA and geomB.

docs.title: Format
docs.text: ST_MaxDistance (A: Geometry, B: Geometry)

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text:
• geomA: Input geometry or geography.
  • geomB: Input geometry or geography.

docs.title: SQL Example
docs.text: SELECT ST_MaxDistance(ST_GeomFromText('POLYGON ((10 10, 11 10, 10 11, 10 10))'), ST_GeomFromText('POLYGON ((0 0, 1 0, 0 1, 0 0))')) AS val

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Returns the maximum M (measure) value from a geometry's bounding box.

docs.title: Format
docs.text: ST_MMax (A: Geometry)

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: • geom: The input geometry.

docs.title: SQL Example
docs.text: SELECT ST_MMax(ST_GeomFromWKT('POLYGON ((0 0, 1 0, 0 1, 0 0))'))

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Returns the minimum M-coordinate (measure) of a geometry's bounding box.

docs.title: Format
docs.text: ST_MMin (A: Geometry)

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: • geom: Input geometry.

docs.title: SQL Example
docs.text:
SELECT ST_MMin(ST_GeomFromWKT('LINESTRING ZM (1 2 3 4, 5 6 7 8)'));
-- Returns: 4

docs.title: Description
docs.text:
This function calculates the 2D perimeter of a given geometry. It supports Polygon, MultiPolygon, and GeometryCollection geometries (as long as the GeometryCollection contains polygonal geometries). For other types, it returns 0. To measure lines, use ST_Length.

To get the perimeter in meters, set use_spheroid to true. This calculates the geodesic perimeter using the WGS84 spheroid. When using use_spheroid, the lenient parameter defaults to true, assuming the geometry uses EPSG:4326. To throw an exception instead, set lenient to false.

docs.title: Format
docs.text: ST_Perimeter(geom: Geometry) ST_Perimeter(geom: Geometry, use_spheroid: Boolean) ST_Perimeter(geom: Geometry, use_spheroid: Boolean, lenient: Boolean = True)

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text:
• geom: Input geometry.
  • use_spheroid: If true, calculates the geodesic perimeter using the WGS84 spheroid. Defaults to false.
  • lenient: If true, assumes the geometry uses EPSG:4326 when use_spheroid is true. Defaults to true.

docs.title: SQL Example
docs.text: SELECT ST_Perimeter(ST_GeomFromWKT('POLYGON((0 0, 10 0, 10 10, 0 10, 0 0))'));

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Construct a Point Geometry from X and Y.

docs.title: Format
docs.text: ST_Point (x: Double, y: Double)

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text:
• x: X value.
  • y: Y value.

docs.title: SQL Example
docs.text: SELECT ST_AsText(ST_Point(-74.0060, 40.7128));

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Constructs a Point with an M (measure) coordinate from X, Y, and M values.

docs.title: Format
docs.text: ST_PointM (x: Double, y: Double, m: Double)

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text:
• x: The X-coordinate value.
  • y: The Y-coordinate value.
  • m: The M-coordinate (measure) value.

docs.title: SQL Example
docs.text: SELECT ST_PointM(-64.36, 45.09, 50.0)

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Constructs a Point with a Z (elevation) coordinate from X, Y, and Z values.

docs.title: Format
docs.text: ST_PointZ (x: Double, y: Double, z: Double)

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text:
• x: The X-coordinate value.
  • y: The Y-coordinate value.
  • z: The Z-coordinate (elevation) value.

docs.title: SQL Example
docs.text: SELECT ST_PointZ(-64.36, 45.09, 100.0)

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Constructs a Point with both Z (elevation) and M (measure) coordinates from X, Y, Z, and M values.

docs.title: Format
docs.text: ST_PointZM (x: Double, y: Double, z: Double, m: Double)

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text:
• x: The X-coordinate value.
  • y: The Y-coordinate value.
  • z: The Z-coordinate (elevation) value.
  • m: The M-coordinate (measure) value.

docs.title: SQL Example
docs.text: SELECT ST_PointZM(-64.36, 45.09, 100.0, 50.0)

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Sets the spatial reference system identifier (SRID) of a geometry. This only changes the metadata; it does not transform the coordinates.

docs.title: Format
docs.text: ST_SetSRID (geom: Geometry, srid: Integer)

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text:
• geom: Input geometry or geography.
  • srid: EPSG code to set (e.g., 4326).

docs.title: SQL Example
docs.text: SELECT ST_SetSRID(ST_GeomFromWKT('POINT (-64.363049 45.091501)'), 4326);

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Returns the Spatial Reference System Identifier (SRID) of a geometry. If the geometry does not have an SRID, it returns 0.

docs.title: Format
docs.text: ST_SRID (geom: Geometry)

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: • geom: The input geometry or geography.

docs.title: SQL Example
docs.text: SELECT ST_SRID(polygon)

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Computes the symmetric difference between geomA and geomB.

docs.title: Format
docs.text: ST_SymDifference (A: Geometry, B: Geometry)

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text:
• geomA: Input geometry or geography.
  • geomB: Input geometry or geography.

docs.title: SQL Example
docs.text: SELECT ST_SymDifference(ST_GeomFromText('POLYGON ((1 1, 11 1, 1 11, 0 0))'), ST_GeomFromText('POLYGON ((0 0, 10 0, 0 10, 0 0))')) AS val

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Return true if geomA touches geomB.

docs.title: Format
docs.text: ST_Touches (A: Geometry, B: Geometry)

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text:
• geomA: Input geometry or geography.
  • geomB: Input geometry or geography.

docs.title: SQL Example
docs.text: SELECT ST_Touches(ST_Point(0.25 0.25), ST_GeomFromText('POLYGON ((0 0, 1 0, 0 1, 0 0))')) AS val

docs.title: Description
docs.text:
Transforms the coordinates of a geometry from a source Coordinate Reference System (CRS) to a target CRS.

If the source CRS is not specified, it will be read from the geometry's metadata. Sedona ensures that coordinates are handled in longitude/latitude order for geographic CRS transformations.

docs.title: Format
docs.text: ST_Transform (A: Geometry, TargetCRS: String) ST_Transform (A: Geometry, SourceCRS: String, TargetCRS: String)

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text:
• geom: Input geometry or geography.
  • source_crs: The source CRS code (e.g., 'EPSG:4326').
  • target_crs: The target CRS code to transform into.
  • lenient: A boolean that, if true, assumes the source is EPSG:4326 if not specified. Defaults to true.

docs.title: SQL Example
docs.text:
-- Transform a WGS84 polygon to UTM zone 49N
SELECT ST_Transform(ST_SetSRID(ST_GeomFromWkt('POLYGON((170 50,170 72,-130 72,-130 50,170 50))'), 4326), 'EPSG:32649');

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Computes the union between geomA and geomB.

docs.title: Format
docs.text: ST_Union (A: Geometry, B: Geometry)

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text:
• geomA: Input geometry or geography.
  • geomB: Input geometry or geography.

docs.title: SQL Example
docs.text: SELECT ST_Union(ST_GeomFromText('POLYGON ((1 1, 11 1, 1 11, 0 0))'), ST_GeomFromText('POLYGON ((0 0, 10 0, 0 10, 0 0))')) AS val

docs.title: Description
docs.text: An aggregate function that returns the geometric union of all geometries in a set.

docs.title: Format
docs.text: ST_Union_Aggr (geom: Geometry)

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: • geom: A column of geometries to be aggregated.

docs.title: SQL Example
docs.text:
-- Create a table with two separate polygons and unite them into a single multipolygon
WITH shapes(geom) AS (
    VALUES (ST_GeomFromWKT('POLYGON ((0 0, 1 0, 1 1, 0 1, 0 0))')),
           (ST_GeomFromWKT('POLYGON ((2 2, 3 2, 3 3, 2 3, 2 2))'))
)
SELECT ST_AsText(ST_Union_Aggr(geom)) FROM shapes;
-- Returns: MULTIPOLYGON (((2 2, 3 2, 3 3, 2 3, 2 2)), ((0 0, 1 0, 1 1, 0 1, 0 0)))

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Return true if geomA is fully contained by geomB.

docs.title: Format
docs.text: ST_Within (A: Geometry, B: Geometry)

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text:
• geomA: Input geometry or geography.
  • geomB: Input geometry or geography.

docs.title: SQL Example
docs.text: SELECT ST_Within(ST_Point(0.25 0.25), ST_GeomFromText('POLYGON ((0 0, 1 0, 0 1, 0 0))')) AS val

docs.title: Description
